text.0_Chapter, 0_Verse: The prophecies of Isaiah son of Amoz, who prophesied concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
text.0_Chapter, 1_Verse:
Hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth,
For the LORD has spoken:
“I reared children and brought them up—
And they have rebelled against Me!
text.0_Chapter, 2_Verse:
An ox knows its owner,
An ass its master’s crib:
Israel does not know,
My people takes no thought.”
text.0_Chapter, 3_Verse:
Ah, sinful nation!
People laden with iniquity!
Brood of evildoers!
Depraved children!
They have forsaken the LORD,
Spurned the Holy One of Israel,
Turned their backs [on Him].
text.0_Chapter, 4_Verse:
Why do you seek further beatings,
That you continue to offend?
Every head is ailing,
And every heart is sick.
text.0_Chapter, 5_Verse:
From head to foot
No spot is sound:
All bruises, and welts,
And festering sores—
Not pressed out, not bound up,
Not softened with oil.
text.0_Chapter, 6_Verse:
Your land is a waste,
Your cities burnt down;
Before your eyes, the yield of your soil
Is consumed by strangers—
A wasteland aEmendation yields “like Sodom overthrown.”as overthrown by strangers!-a
text.0_Chapter, 7_Verse:
FairbLit. “Daughter.” Zion is left
Like a booth in a vineyard,
Like a hut in a cucumber field,
Like a city beleaguered.
text.0_Chapter, 8_Verse:
Had not the LORD of Hosts
Left us some survivors,
We should be like Sodom,
Another Gomorrah.
text.0_Chapter, 9_Verse:
Hear the word of the LORD,
You chieftains of Sodom;
Give ear to our God’s instruction,
You folk of Gomorrah!
text.0_Chapter, 10_Verse:
“What need have I of all your sacrifices?”
Says the LORD.
“I am sated with burnt offerings of rams,
And suet of fatlings,
And blood of bulls;
And I have no delight
In lambs and he-goats.
text.0_Chapter, 11_Verse:
That you come to appear before Me—
Who asked that cOthers “To trample My courts? / 13Bring no more vain oblations.”of you?
Trample My courts
text.0_Chapter, 12_Verse:
no more;
Bringing oblations is futile,-c
Incense is offensive to Me.
New moon and sabbath,
Proclaiming of solemnities,
dSeptuagint “Fast and assembly”; cf. Joel 1.14.Assemblies with iniquity,-d
I cannot abide.
text.0_Chapter, 13_Verse:
Your new moons and fixed seasons
Fill Me with loathing;
They are become a burden to Me,
I cannot endure them.
text.0_Chapter, 14_Verse:
And when you lift up your hands,
I will turn My eyes away from you;
Though you pray at length,
I will not listen.
Your hands are stained with crime—
text.0_Chapter, 15_Verse:
Wash yourselves clean;
Put your evil doings
Away from My sight.
Cease to do evil;
text.0_Chapter, 16_Verse:
Learn to do good.
Devote yourselves to justice;
eMeaning of Heb. uncertain.Aid the wronged.-e
Uphold the rights of the orphan;
Defend the cause of the widow.
text.0_Chapter, 17_Verse:
“Come, eMeaning of Heb. uncertain.let us reach an understanding,-e
—says the LORD.
Be your sins like crimson,
They can turn snow-white;
Be they red as dyed wool,
They can become like fleece.”
text.0_Chapter, 18_Verse:
If, then, you agree and give heed,
You will eat the good things of the earth;
text.0_Chapter, 19_Verse:
But if you refuse and disobey,
fOr “you will be fed the sword.”You will be devoured [by] the sword.-f—
For it was the LORD who spoke.
text.0_Chapter, 20_Verse:
Alas, she has become a harlot,
The faithful city
That was filled with justice,
Where righteousness dwelt—
But now murderers.
text.0_Chapter, 21_Verse:
YourgI.e., Jerusalem’s. silver has turned to dross;
eMeaning of Heb. uncertain.Your wine is cut with water.-e
text.0_Chapter, 22_Verse:
Your rulers are rogues
And cronies of thieves,
Every one avid for presents
And greedy for gifts;
They do not judge the case of the orphan,
And the widow’s cause never reaches them.
text.0_Chapter, 23_Verse:
Assuredly, this is the declaration
Of the Sovereign, the LORD of Hosts,
The Mighty One of Israel:
“Ah, I will get satisfaction from My foes;
I will wreak vengeance on My enemies!
text.0_Chapter, 24_Verse:
I will turn My hand against you,
And smelt out your dross hEmendation yields “in a crucible”; cf. 48.10.as with lye,-h
And remove all your slag:
text.0_Chapter, 25_Verse:
I will restore your magistrates as of old,
And your counselors as of yore.
After that you shall be called
City of Righteousness, Faithful City.”
text.0_Chapter, 26_Verse:
iOthers “Zion shall be saved by justice, / Her repentant ones by righteousness.”Zion shall be saved in the judgment;
Her repentant ones, in the retribution.jFor this meaning cf. 5.16; 10.22.
text.0_Chapter, 27_Verse:
But rebels and sinners shall all be crushed,
And those who forsake the LORD shall perish.
text.0_Chapter, 28_Verse:
Truly, youkHeb. “they.” shall be shamed
Because of the terebinths you desired,
And you shall be confounded
Because of the gardens you coveted.
text.0_Chapter, 29_Verse:
For you shall be like a terebinth
Wilted of leaf,
And like a garden
That has no water,
text.0_Chapter, 30_Verse:
lConnecting ḥason with ḥasan, “to store” (23.18), and ḥosen, “treasure” (33.6).Stored wealth-l shall become as tow,
And he who amassed it a spark;
And the two shall burn together,
With none to quench.
text.1_Chapter, 0_Verse: The word that Isaiah son of Amoz prophesied concerning Judah and Jerusalem.
text.1_Chapter, 1_Verse:
In the days to come,
The Mount of the LORD’s House
Shall stand firm above the mountains
And tower above the hills;
And all the nations
Shall gaze on it with joy.
text.1_Chapter, 2_Verse:
And the many peoples shall go and say:
“Come,
Let us go up to the Mount of the LORD,
To the House of the God of Jacob;
That He may instruct us in His ways,
And that we may walk in His paths.”
For instruction shall come forthaI.e., oracles will be obtainable. from Zion,
The word of the LORD from Jerusalem.
text.1_Chapter, 3_Verse:
Thus He will judge among the nations
And arbitrate for the many peoples,
And they shall beat their swords into plowsharesbMore exactly, the iron points with which wooden plows were tipped.
And their spears into pruning hooks:
Nation shall not take up
Sword against nation;
They shall never again knowcCf. Judg. 3.2. war.
text.1_Chapter, 4_Verse:
O House of Jacob!
Come, let us walk
By the light of the LORD.
text.1_Chapter, 5_Verse:
For you have forsaken [the ways of] your people,
O House of Jacob!
dEmendation yields “For they are full of divination / and have abundance of soothsaying, / Like Philistines / And like alien folk.”For they are full [of practices] from the East,
And of soothsaying like the Philistines;
They abound in customseCf. Targum; lit. “children.” of the aliens.-d
text.1_Chapter, 6_Verse:
Their land is full of silver and gold,
There is no limit to their treasures;
Their land is full of horses,
There is no limit to their chariots.
text.1_Chapter, 7_Verse:
And their land is full of idols;
They bow down to the work of their hands,
To what their own fingers have wrought.
text.1_Chapter, 8_Verse:
But man shall be humbled,
And mortal brought low—
fMeaning of Heb. uncertain. Emendation yields “And their idols with them”; cf. vv. 17–21.Oh, do not forgive them!-f
text.1_Chapter, 9_Verse:
Go deep into the rock,
Bury yourselves in the ground,
Before the terror of the LORD
And His dread majesty!
text.1_Chapter, 10_Verse:
Man’s haughty look shall be brought low,
And the pride of mortals shall be humbled.
None but the LORD shall be
Exalted in that day.
text.1_Chapter, 11_Verse:
For the LORD of Hosts has ready a day
Against all that is proud and arrogant,
Against all that is lofty—so that it is brought low:
text.1_Chapter, 12_Verse:
Against all the cedars of Lebanon,
Tall and stately,
And all the oaks of Bashan;
text.1_Chapter, 13_Verse:
Against all the high mountains
And all the lofty hills;
text.1_Chapter, 14_Verse:
Against every soaring tower
And every mighty wall;
text.1_Chapter, 15_Verse:
Against all the gProbably a type of large ship.ships of Tarshish-g
And all the gallant barks.
text.1_Chapter, 16_Verse:
Then man’s haughtiness shall be humbled
And the pride of man brought low.
None but the LORD shall be
Exalted in that day.
text.1_Chapter, 17_Verse: As for idols, they shall vanish completely.
text.1_Chapter, 18_Verse:
And men shall enter caverns in the rock
And hollows in the ground—
Before the terror of the LORD
And His dread majesty,
When He comes forth to overawe the earth.
text.1_Chapter, 19_Verse:
On that day, men shall fling away,
To the hExact meaning of Heb. uncertain.flying foxes-h and the bats,
The idols of silver
And the idols of gold
Which they made for worshiping.
text.1_Chapter, 20_Verse:
And they shall enter the clefts in the rocks
And the crevices in the cliffs,
Before the terror of the LORD
And His dread majesty,
When He comes forth to overawe the earth.
text.1_Chapter, 21_Verse:
Oh, cease to glorify man,
Who has only a breath in his nostrils!
For by what does he merit esteem?
text.2_Chapter, 0_Verse:
For lo!
The Sovereign LORD of Hosts
Will remove from Jerusalem and from Judah
Prop and stay,
Every prop of food
And every prop of water:aEmendation yields “clothing”; cf. v. 7; 4.1.
text.2_Chapter, 1_Verse:
Soldier and warrior,
Magistrate and prophet,
Augur and elder;
text.2_Chapter, 2_Verse:
Captain of fifty,
Magnate and counselor,
Skilled artisan and expert enchanter;bEmendation yields “craftsman.”
text.2_Chapter, 3_Verse:
And HecHeb. “I.” will make boys their rulers,
And babes shall govern them.
text.2_Chapter, 4_Verse:
So the people shall oppress one another—
Each oppressing his fellow:
The young shall bully the old;
And the despised [shall bully] the honored.
text.2_Chapter, 5_Verse:
For should a man seize his brother,
dEmendation yields “His father’s son, saying…”In whose father’s house there is clothing:-d
“Come, be a chief over us,
And let this ruineMeaning of Heb. uncertain. Emendation yields “wound.” be under your care,”
text.2_Chapter, 6_Verse:
The other will thereupon protest,
“I will not be a dresser of wounds,
With no food or clothing in my own house.
You shall not make me chief of a people!”
text.2_Chapter, 7_Verse:
Ah, Jerusalem has stumbled,
And Judah has fallen,
Because by word and deed
They insult the LORD,
Defying His majestic glance.
text.2_Chapter, 8_Verse:
Their partiality in judgmentfSo Targum; cf. Deut. 1.17; 16.19. accuses them;
They avow their sins like Sodom,
They do not conceal them.
Woe to them! For ill
Have they served themselves.
text.2_Chapter, 9_Verse:
(HailgEmendation yields “Happy is.” the just man, for he shall fare well;
He shall eat the fruit of his works.
text.2_Chapter, 10_Verse:
Woe to the wicked man, for he shall fare ill;
As his hands have dealt, so shall it be done to him.)
text.2_Chapter, 11_Verse:
My people’s rulers are babes,
It is governed by women.hEmendation yields “boys”; cf. v. 4 (and v. 5).
O my people!
Your leaders are misleaders;
They have confused the course of your paths.
text.2_Chapter, 12_Verse:
The LORD stands up to plead a cause,
He rises to champion peoples.iSeptuagint “His people”; cf. vv. 14, 15.
text.2_Chapter, 13_Verse:
The LORD will bring this charge
Against the elders and officers of His people:
“It is you who have ravaged the vineyard;
That which was robbed from the poor is in your houses.
text.2_Chapter, 14_Verse:
How dare you crush My people
And grind the faces of the poor?”
—says my Lord GOD of Hosts.
text.2_Chapter, 15_Verse:
The LORD said:
“Because the daughters of Zion
Are so vain
And walk with jLit. “throats bent back.”heads thrown back,-j
With roving eyes,
And with mincing gait,
Making a tinkling with their feet”—
text.2_Chapter, 16_Verse:
My Lord will barekSo Saadia. To bare a woman’s head in public was an intolerable humiliation; cf. Mishnah Baba Kamma 8.6. the pates
Of the daughters of Zion,
The LORD will uncover their heads.
text.2_Chapter, 17_Verse: In that day, my LORD will strip off the finerylMany of the articles named in vv. 18–24 cannot be identified with certainty. of the anklets, the fillets, and the crescents;
text.2_Chapter, 18_Verse: of the eardrops, the bracelets, and the veils;
text.2_Chapter, 19_Verse: the turbans, the armlets, and the sashes; of the talismans and the amulets;
text.2_Chapter, 20_Verse: the signet rings and the nose rings;
text.2_Chapter, 21_Verse: of the festive robes, the mantles, and the shawls; the purses,
text.2_Chapter, 22_Verse: the lace gowns, and the linen vests; and the kerchiefs and the capes.
text.2_Chapter, 23_Verse:
And then—
Instead of perfume, there shall be rot;
And instead of an apron, a rope;
Instead of a diadem of beaten-work,
A shorn head;
Instead of a rich robe,
A girding of sackcloth;
mThe complete Isaiah scroll from Qumran, hereafter 1QIsa, reads “For shame shall take the place of beauty”; cf. note k.A burn instead of beauty.-m
text.2_Chapter, 24_Verse:
HernI.e., Zion’s; cf. vv. 16, 17; Heb. “your.” men shall fall by the sword,
Her fighting manhood in battle;
text.2_Chapter, 25_Verse:
And her gates shall lament and mourn,
And oMeaning of Heb. uncertain. Emendation yields “her wall”; cf. Lam. 2.8.she shall be emptied,-o
Shall sit on the ground.
text.3_Chapter, 0_Verse:
In that day, seven women shall take hold of one man, saying,
“We will eat our own food
And wear our own clothes;
Only let us be called by your name—
Take away our disgrace!”
text.3_Chapter, 1_Verse:
aFor the interpretation of this verse, cf. 28.5. For “radiance,” cf. Septuagint and the Syriac ṣemḥa, and for “splendor,” cf. the meaning of peri in 10.12.In that day,
The radiance of the LORD
Will lend beauty and glory,
And the splendor of bEmendation yields “my Lord”; cf. the parallelism (in reverse order) in 3.17.the land-b
[Will give] dignity and majesty,
To the survivors of Israel.
text.3_Chapter, 2_Verse:
And those who remain in Zion
And are left in Jerusalem—
All who are inscribed for life in Jerusalem—
Shall be called holy.
text.3_Chapter, 3_Verse:
When my Lord has washed away
The filth of cEmendation yields “Daughter Zion,” i.e., Zion personified; cf. 1.8 and note.the daughters of Zion,-c
And from Jerusalem’s midst
Has rinsed out her infamy—
In a spirit of judgment
And in a spirit of purging—
text.3_Chapter, 4_Verse: the LORD will createdEmendation yields “spread”; cf. Ps. 105.39. over the whole shrine and meeting place of Mount Zion cloud by day and smoke with a glow of flaming fire by night. Indeed, over eEmendation yields “His whole shrine.”all the glory-e shall hang a canopy,
text.3_Chapter, 5_Verse: which shall serve as a pavilion for shade from heat by day and as a shelter for protection against drenching rain.
text.4_Chapter, 0_Verse:
Let me sing for my beloved
A song of my lover about his vineyard.

My beloved had a vineyard
aMeaning of Heb. uncertain.On a fruitful hill.-a
text.4_Chapter, 1_Verse:
He broke the ground, cleared it of stones,
And planted it with choice vines.
He built a watchtower inside it,
He even hewed a wine press in it;
For he hoped it would yield grapes.
Instead, it yielded wild grapes.
text.4_Chapter, 2_Verse:
“Now, then,
Dwellers of Jerusalem
And men of Judah,
You be the judges
Between Me and My vineyard:
text.4_Chapter, 3_Verse:
What more could have been done for My vineyard
That I failed to do in it?
Why, when I hoped it would yield grapes,
Did it yield wild grapes?
text.4_Chapter, 4_Verse:
“Now I am going to tell you
What I will do to My vineyard:
I will remove its hedge,
That it may be ravaged;
I will break down its wall,
That it may be trampled.
text.4_Chapter, 5_Verse:
And I will aMeaning of Heb. uncertain.make it a desolation;-a
It shall not be pruned or hoed,
And it shall be overgrown with briers and thistles.
And I will command the clouds
To drop no rain on it.”
text.4_Chapter, 6_Verse:
For the vineyard of the LORD of Hosts
Is the House of Israel,
And the seedlings he lovingly tended
Are the men of Judah.
bThis sentence contains two word-plays: “And He hoped for mishpat·, And there is mispaḥ [exact meaning uncertain]; / For ṣedaqah, But there is ṣe‘aqah [lit. ‘outcry’].”And He hoped for justice,
But behold, injustice;
For equity,
But behold, iniquity!
text.4_Chapter, 7_Verse:
Ah,
Those who add house to house
And join field to field,
Till there is room for none but you
To dwell in the land!
text.4_Chapter, 8_Verse:
In my hearing [said] the LORD of Hosts:
Surely, great houses
Shall lie forlorn,
Spacious and splendid ones
Without occupants.
text.4_Chapter, 9_Verse:
For ten acres of vineyard
Shall yield just one bath,cI.e., of wine. The bath was the liquid equivalent of the ephah; and the ḥomer was ten baths or ephahs (Ezek. 45.11).
And a field sown with a ḥomer of seed
Shall yield a mere ephah.
text.4_Chapter, 10_Verse:
Ah,
Those who chase liquor
From early in the morning,
And till late in the evening
Are inflamed by wine!
text.4_Chapter, 11_Verse:
dEmendation yields “whose interests are” (mish‘ehem, from sha‘ah “to turn to,” 17.7, 8; 31.1).Who, at their banquets,
Have-d lyre and lute,
Timbrel, flute, and wine;
But who never give a thought
To the plan of the LORD,
And take no note
Of what He is designing.
text.4_Chapter, 12_Verse:
Assuredly,
My people will suffer exile
For not giving heed,
Its multitude victims of hunger
And its masses parched with thirst.
text.4_Chapter, 13_Verse:
Assuredly,
Sheol has opened wide its gullet
And parted its jaws in a measureless gape;
And down into it shall go,
That splendor and tumult,
That din and revelry.
text.4_Chapter, 14_Verse:
Yea, man is bowed,
And mortal brought low;
Brought low is the pride of the haughty.
text.4_Chapter, 15_Verse:
And the LORD of Hosts is exalted by judgment,
The Holy God proved holy by retribution.
text.4_Chapter, 16_Verse:
eMeaning of verse uncertain. Emendation yields “The lambs shall graze / In the pasture of the fat [rams], / And the kids shall feed / On the ranges of the stout [bucks].” The lambs and the kids are the poor and the rams and bucks are the rich oppressors (cf. Ezek. 34.17–22).Then lambs shall graze
As in their meadows,
And strangers shall feed
On the ruins of the stout.
text.4_Chapter, 17_Verse:
Ah,
Those who haul sin with cords of falsehood
And iniquity as with cart ropes!
text.4_Chapter, 18_Verse:
Who say,fBy way of retort to v. 12.
“Let Him speed, let Him hasten His purpose,
If we are to give thought;
Let the plans of the Holy One of Israel
Be quickly fulfilled,
If we are to give heed.”
text.4_Chapter, 19_Verse:
Ah,
Those who call evil good
And good evil;
Who present darkness as light
And light as darkness;
Who present bitter as sweet
And sweet as bitter!
text.4_Chapter, 20_Verse:
Ah,
Those who are so wise—
In their own opinion;
So clever—
In their own judgment!
text.4_Chapter, 21_Verse:
Ah,
Those who are so doughty—
As drinkers of wine,
And so valiant—
As mixers of drink!
text.4_Chapter, 22_Verse:
Who vindicate him who is in the wrong
In return for a bribe,
And withhold vindication
From him who is in the right.
text.4_Chapter, 23_Verse:
Assuredly,
As straw is consumed by a tongue of fire
And hay gEmendation yields “is burned by flame”; cf. 33.11–12; 47.14.shrivels as it burns,-g
Their stock shall become like rot,
And their buds shall blow away like dust.
For they have rejected the instruction of the LORD of Hosts,
Spurned the word of the Holy One of Israel.
text.4_Chapter, 24_Verse:
That is why
The LORD’s anger was roused
Against His people,
Why He stretched out His arm against it
And struck it,
So that the mountains quaked,hAn allusion to the destructive earthquake in the reign of King Uzziah: Amos 1.1; Zech. 14.5; cf. Isa. 9.18a.
And its corpses lay
Like refuse in the streets.
Yet His anger has not turned back,
And His arm is outstretched still.
text.4_Chapter, 25_Verse:
He will raise an ensign to a nationiHeb. “nations.” afar,
Whistle to one at the end of the earth.
There it comes with lightning speed!
text.4_Chapter, 26_Verse:
In its ranks, none is weary or stumbles,
They never sleep or slumber;
The belts on their waists do not come loose,
Nor do the thongs of their sandals break.
text.4_Chapter, 27_Verse:
Their arrows are sharpened,
And all their bows are drawn.
Their horses’ hoofs are like flint,
Their chariot wheels like the whirlwind.
text.4_Chapter, 28_Verse:
Their roaring is like a lion’s,
They roar like the great beasts;
When they growl and seize a prey,
They carry it off and none can recover it.
text.4_Chapter, 29_Verse:
But in that day, a roaring shall resound over him like that of the sea;jI.e., the Lord will intervene and come to his aid. Cf. 29.6–7; 30.27. This verse may constitute a transition between chaps. 8 and 9. and then he shall look below and, behold,
Distressing darkness, with light;
Darkness, aMeaning of Heb. uncertain.in its lowering clouds.-a
text.5_Chapter, 0_Verse: In the year that King Uzziah died, I beheld my Lord seated on a high and lofty throne; and the skirts of His robe filled the Temple.
text.5_Chapter, 1_Verse: Seraphs stood in attendance on Him. Each of them had six wings: with two he covered his face, with two he covered his legs, and with two he would fly.
text.5_Chapter, 2_Verse:
And one would call to the other,
“Holy, holy, holy!
The LORD of Hosts!
His presence fills all the earth!”
text.5_Chapter, 3_Verse: The doorpostsaMeaning of Heb. uncertain. would shake at the sound of the one who called, and the House kept filling with smoke.
text.5_Chapter, 4_Verse:
I cried,
“Woe is me; I am lost!
For I am a man bI.e., speaking impiety; cf. 9.16, and contrast “pure of speech [lit. ‘lip’]” in Zeph. 3.9.of unclean lips-b
And I live among a people
Of unclean lips;
Yet my own eyes have beheld
The King LORD of Hosts.”
text.5_Chapter, 5_Verse: Then one of the seraphs flew over to me with a live coal, which he had taken from the altar with a pair of tongs.
text.5_Chapter, 6_Verse:
He touched it to my lips and declared,

“Now that this has touched your lips,
Your guilt shall depart
And your sin be purged away.”
text.5_Chapter, 7_Verse: Then I heard the voice of my Lord saying, “Whom shall I send? Who will go for us?” And I said, “Here am I; send me.”
text.5_Chapter, 8_Verse:
And He said, “Go, say to that people:
‘Hear, indeed, but do not understand;
See, indeed, but do not grasp.’
text.5_Chapter, 9_Verse:
Dull that people’s mind,
Stop its ears,
And seal its eyes—
Lest, seeing with its eyes
And hearing with its ears,
It also grasp with its mind,
And repent and savecLit. “heal.” itself.”
text.5_Chapter, 10_Verse:
I asked, “How long, my Lord?” And He replied:
“Till towns lie waste without inhabitants
And houses without people,
And the ground lies waste and desolate—
text.5_Chapter, 11_Verse:
For the LORD will banish the population—
And deserted sites are many
In the midst of the land.
text.5_Chapter, 12_Verse: “But while a tenth part yet remains in it, it shall repent. It shall be ravaged like the terebinth and the oak, of which stumps are left even when they are felled: its stump shall be a holy seed.”
text.6_Chapter, 0_Verse: In the reign of Ahaz son of Jotham son of Uzziah, king of Judah, King Rezin of Aram and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel marched upon Jerusalem to attack it; but they were not able to attack it.
text.6_Chapter, 1_Verse: Now, when it was reported to the House of David that Aram had allied itself with Ephraim, their hearts and the hearts of their people trembled as trees of the forest sway before a wind.
text.6_Chapter, 2_Verse: But the LORD said to Isaiah, “Go out with your son Shear-jashubaMeaning “[only] a remnant will turn back,” i.e., repent; cf. 6.13; 10.21. to meet Ahaz at the end of the conduit of the Upper Pool, by the road of the Fuller’s Field.
text.6_Chapter, 3_Verse: And say to him: Be firm and be calm. Do not be afraid and do not lose heart on account of those two smoking stubs of firebrands, on account of the raging of Rezin and his Arameans and the son of Remaliah.bTo refer to a person only as “the son of—” is slighting; cf. note at 1 Sam. 10.11.
text.6_Chapter, 4_Verse: Because the Arameans—with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah—have plotted against you, saying,
text.6_Chapter, 5_Verse: ‘We will march against Judah and invade and conquer it, and we will set up as king in it the son of Tabeel,’bTo refer to a person only as “the son of—” is slighting; cf. note at 1 Sam. 10.11.
text.6_Chapter, 6_Verse:
thus said my Lord GOD:
It shall not succeed,
It shall not come to pass.
text.6_Chapter, 7_Verse:
For the chief city of Aram is Damascus,
And the chief of Damascus is Rezin;
text.6_Chapter, 8_Verse:
The chief city of Ephraim is Samaria,
And the chief of Samaria is the son of Remaliah.cThe thought is continued by 8.8b–10; cf. 2 Chron. 13.8–12.
dBrought down from v. 8 for clarity.And in another sixty-five years,
Ephraim shall be shattered as a people.-d
If you will not believe, for you eOthers “surely, you shall not be established.”cannot be trusted-e…”
text.6_Chapter, 9_Verse: The L<small>ORD</small> spoke further to Ahaz:
text.6_Chapter, 10_Verse: “Ask for a sign from the L<small>ORD</small> your God, anywhere down to Sheol or up to the sky.”
text.6_Chapter, 11_Verse: But Ahaz replied, “I will not ask, and I will not test the L<small>ORD</small>.”
text.6_Chapter, 12_Verse: “Listen, House of David,” [Isaiah] retorted, “is it not enough for you to treat men as helpless that you also treat my God as helpless?fBy insisting on soliciting the aid of Assyria (see 2 Kings 16.7 ff.; cf. below, v. 20). “Treat as helpless” follows the translation of Saadia; cf. Gen. 19.11.
text.6_Chapter, 13_Verse: Assuredly, my Lord will give you a sign of His own accord! Look, the young woman is with child and about to give birth to a son. Let her name him Immanuel.gMeaning “with us is God.”
text.6_Chapter, 14_Verse: (By the time he learns to reject the bad and choose the good, people will be feeding on curds and honey.)
text.6_Chapter, 15_Verse: For before the lad knows to reject the bad and choose the good, the ground whose two kings you dread shall be abandoned.
text.6_Chapter, 16_Verse: The LORD will cause to come upon you and your people and your ancestral house such days as never have come since Ephraim turned away from Judah—that selfsame king of Assyria!hCf. note on v. 13.
text.6_Chapter, 17_Verse: “In that day, the L<small>ORD</small> will whistle to the flies at the ends of the water channels of Egypt and to the bees in the land of Assyria;
text.6_Chapter, 18_Verse: and they shall all come and alight in the rugged wadis, and in the clefts of the rocks, and in all the thornbrakes, and in all the watering places.
text.6_Chapter, 19_Verse: “In that day, my Lord will cut away with the razor that is hired beyond the Euphrates—with the king of AssyriaiWho was hired by Ahaz; cf. notes on vv. 13 and 17.—the hair of the head and jI.e., the pubic hair.the hair of the legs,-j and it shall clip off the beard as well.
text.6_Chapter, 20_Verse: And in that day, each man shall save alive a heifer of the herd and two animals of the flock.
text.6_Chapter, 21_Verse: (And he shall obtain so much milk that he shall eat curds.) Thus everyone who is left in the land shall feed on curds and honey.
text.6_Chapter, 22_Verse: “For in that day, every spot where there could stand a thousand vines worth a thousand shekels of silverkI.e., all the best farm land, corresponding to the hairiest parts of the body; v. 20. shall become a wilderness of thornbush and thistle.
text.6_Chapter, 23_Verse: One will have to go there with bow and arrows,lBecause of dangerous beasts. for the country shall be all thornbushes and thistles.
text.6_Chapter, 24_Verse: But the perils of thornbush and thistle shall not spread to any of the hills that could only be tilled with a hoe;mMarginal farm land, too rocky for the plow, corresponding to areas of the body with scant hair. and here cattle shall be let loose, and nSee note at Exod. 12.3.sheep and goats-n shall tramp about.”
text.7_Chapter, 0_Verse: The LORD said to me, “Get yourself a large sheet and write on it aMeaning of Heb. uncertain.in common script-a ‘For Maher-shalal-hash-baz’;bI.e., “Pillage hastens, looting speeds,” indicating that two cities are to be pillaged at an early date; see v. 4.
text.7_Chapter, 1_Verse: and call reliable witnesses, the priest Uriah and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah, to witness for Me.”
text.7_Chapter, 2_Verse: I was intimate with the prophetess,cI.e., Isaiah’s wife. and she conceived and bore a son; and the LORD said to me, “Name him Maher-shalal-hash-baz.bI.e., “Pillage hastens, looting speeds,” indicating that two cities are to be pillaged at an early date; see v. 4.
text.7_Chapter, 3_Verse: For before the boy learns to call ‘Father’ and ‘Mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the spoils of Samaria, dBrought up from v. 6 for clarity.and the delights of Rezin and of the son of Remaliah,-d shall be carried off before the king of Assyria.”
text.7_Chapter, 4_Verse: Again the L<small>ORD</small> spoke to me, thus:
text.7_Chapter, 5_Verse:
“Because that people has spurned
The gently flowing waters of Siloam”eThe conduit—and later the tunnel—of Siloam conveyed into Jerusalem the waters of Gihon, which symbolize “the Lord of Hosts who dwells on Mount Zion” (v. 18). For the nature of the rejection see note at 7.13.—
text.7_Chapter, 6_Verse:
Assuredly,
My Lord will bring up against them
The mighty, massive waters of the Euphrates,
The king of Assyria and all his multitude.
It shall rise above all its channels,
And flow over all its beds,
text.7_Chapter, 7_Verse:
And swirl through Judah like a flash flood
Reaching up to the neck.fI.e., Judah shall be imperiled, but, in contrast to Aram and Ephraim (v. 4), not destroyed.

gSee note c at 7.9.But with us is God,
Whose wings are spread
As wide as your land is broad!
text.7_Chapter, 8_Verse:
Band together, O peoples—you shall be broken!
Listen to this, you remotest parts of the earth:
Gird yourselves—you shall be broken;
Gird yourselves—you shall be broken!
text.7_Chapter, 9_Verse:
Hatch a plot—it shall be foiled;
Agree on action—it shall not succeed.
For with us is God!
text.7_Chapter, 10_Verse: For this is what the LORD said to me, when He took me by the handhI.e., singled me out; cf. 41.9, 13; 42.6; 45.1; Jer. 31.32 [31]. and charged me not to walk in the path of that people:
text.7_Chapter, 11_Verse:
iThe Heb. forms here and in vv. 13 and 19 are plural to include the disciples (v. 16) and the children (v. 18).“You must not call conspiracyjMeaning of Heb. uncertain. Emendation yields “holy”; cf. v. 13.
All that that people calls conspiracy,jMeaning of Heb. uncertain. Emendation yields “holy”; cf. v. 13.
Nor revere what it reveres,
Nor hold it in awe.
text.7_Chapter, 12_Verse:
None but the LORD of Hosts
Shall you account holy;
Give reverence to Him alone,
Hold Him alone in awe.
text.7_Chapter, 13_Verse:
He shall be kEmendation yields “…for His holy domain [cf. Ps. 114.2] / A stone…”for a sanctuary,
A stone-k men strike against:
A rock men stumble over
For the two Houses of Israel,
And a trap and a snare for those
Who dwell in Jerusalem.
text.7_Chapter, 14_Verse:
The masses shall trip over these
And shall fall and be injured,
Shall be snared and be caught.
text.7_Chapter, 15_Verse:
Bind up the message,
Seal the instruction with My disciples.”
text.7_Chapter, 16_Verse: So I will wait for the L<small>ORD</small>, who is hiding His face from the House of Jacob, and I will trust in Him.
text.7_Chapter, 17_Verse: Here stand I and the children the L<small>ORD</small> has given me as signs and portents in Israel from the L<small>ORD</small> of Hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.
text.7_Chapter, 18_Verse: Now, should people say to you, “Inquire of the ghosts and familiar spirits that chirp and moan; for a people may inquire of its divine beingslI.e., the shades of the dead; cf. 1 Sam. 28.13.—of the dead on behalf of the living—
text.7_Chapter, 19_Verse: for instruction and message,” surely, for one who speaks thus there shall be no dawn.
text.7_Chapter, 20_Verse: mThis sentence would read well after v. 22.And he shall go about in it wretched and hungry; and when he is hungry, he shall rage and revolt against his king and his divine beings.-m He may turn his face upward
text.7_Chapter, 21_Verse:
or he may look below, but behold,
Distress and darkness, nMeaning of Heb. uncertain.with no daybreak;-n
Straitness and gloom, nMeaning of Heb. uncertain.with no dawn.-n
text.7_Chapter, 22_Verse: For oSo 1QIsa; the others have “there is not.”if there were to be-o any break of day for that [land] which is in straits, only the former [king] would have brought abasement to the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali—while the later one would have brought honor to the Way of the Sea, the other side of the Jordan, and Galilee of the Nations.pMeaning of verse uncertain. The rendering here assumes that “the former [king]” refers to Pekah (cf. 2 Kings 15.29) and “the later” to Hoshea (ibid. 30). For the construction lu…ka’eth, see Judg. 13–23.
text.8_Chapter, 0_Verse:
aSee note j at 5.30.The people that walked in darkness
Have seen a brilliant light;
On those who dwelt in a land of gloom
Light has dawned.
text.8_Chapter, 1_Verse:
You have magnified that nation,
Have given it great joy;
They have rejoiced before You
As they rejoice at reaping time,
As they exult
When dividing spoil.
text.8_Chapter, 2_Verse:
For the yoke that they bore
And the stick on their back—
The rod of their taskmaster—
You have broken as on the day of Midian.bSee Judg. 7–8.
text.8_Chapter, 3_Verse:
Truly, all the boots put on cMeaning of Heb. uncertain; emendation yields “in wickedness”; cf. Targum.to stamp with-c
And all the garments donned in infamy
Have been fed to the flames,
Devoured by fire.
text.8_Chapter, 4_Verse:
For a child has been born to us,
A son has been given us.
And authority has settled on his shoulders.
He has been named
“The Mighty God is planning grace;dAs in 25.1.
The Eternal Father, a peaceable ruler”—
text.8_Chapter, 5_Verse:
In token of abundant authority
And of peace without limit
Upon David’s throne and kingdom,
That it may be firmly established
In justice and in equity
Now and evermore.
The zeal of the LORD of Hosts
Shall bring this to pass.
text.8_Chapter, 6_Verse:
My Lord
eSeptuagint reads “Let loose pestilence”; cf. Amos 4.10. In vv. 7–20 Isaiah alludes to and builds upon Amos 4.10–12.Let loose a word-e against Jacob
And it fell upon Israel.
text.8_Chapter, 7_Verse:
But all the people notedf1QIsa reads “shouted.”—
Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria—
In arrogance and haughtiness:
text.8_Chapter, 8_Verse:
“Bricks have fallen—
We’ll rebuild with dressed stone;
Sycamores have been felled—
We’ll grow cedars instead!”
text.8_Chapter, 9_Verse:
So the LORD let gEmendation yields “its enemies.”the enemies of Rezin-g
Triumph over it
And stirred up its foes—
text.8_Chapter, 10_Verse:
Aram from the east
And Philistia from the west—
Who devoured Israel
With greedy mouths.

Yet His anger has not turned back,
And His arm is outstretched still.
text.8_Chapter, 11_Verse:
For the people has not turned back
To Him who struck it
And has not sought
The LORD of Hosts.
text.8_Chapter, 12_Verse:
So the LORD will cut off from Israel
Head and tail,
Palm branch and reed,
In a single day.
text.8_Chapter, 13_Verse:
Elders hEmendation yields “who practice partiality.”and magnates-h—
Such are the heads;
Prophets who give false instruction,
Such are the tailsiEmendation yields “palm branches”; the elders and the prophets are the leaders, the people are the led; cf. 3.1–2, 12.
text.8_Chapter, 14_Verse:
That people’s leaders have been misleaders,
So they that are led have been confused.
text.8_Chapter, 15_Verse:
That is why my Lord
Will not sparejCf. Arabic samuḥa. 1QIsa reads yḥmw. their youths,
Nor show compassion
To their orphans and widows;
For all are ungodly and wicked,
And every mouth speaks impiety.
text.8_Chapter, 16_Verse:
Already wickedness has blazed forth like a fire
Devouring thorn and thistle.
It has kindled the thickets of the wood,
kMeaning of Heb. uncertain.Which have turned into billowing smoke.-k

lMoved down from v. 16 for clarity.Yet His anger has not turned back,
And His arm is outstretched still.-l
text.8_Chapter, 17_Verse:
By the fury of the LORD of Hosts,
The earth was shaken.mCf. note at 5.25.
Next, the people became like devouring fire:
No man spared his countryman.
text.8_Chapter, 18_Verse:
They snatched on the right, but remained hungry,
And consumed on the left without being sated.
Each devoured the flesh of his nMeaning of Heb. uncertain. Emendation yields “fellow”; cf. Targum.own kindred-n—
text.8_Chapter, 19_Verse:
Manasseh Ephraim’s, and Ephraim Manasseh’s,oAlludes to the civil wars of 2 Kings 15.10, 14–16, 25.
And both of them against Judah!pCf. 7.1–9.

Yet His anger has not turned back,
And His arm is outstretched still.
text.9_Chapter, 0_Verse:
Ha!
Those who write out evil writs
And compose iniquitous documents,
text.9_Chapter, 1_Verse:
To subvert the cause of the poor,
To rob of their rights the needy of My people;
That widows may be their spoil,
And fatherless children their booty!
text.9_Chapter, 2_Verse:
What will you do on the day of punishment,
When the calamity comes from afar?
To whom will you flee for help,
And how will you save your carcassesaMeaning of Heb. uncertain; for “carcasses,” compare the rendering of kabod in v. 16; 22.18.
text.9_Chapter, 3_Verse:
From collapsing under [fellow] prisoners,
From falling beneath the slain?

Yet His anger has not turned back,
And his arm is outstretched still.
text.9_Chapter, 4_Verse:
Ha!
Assyria, rod of My anger,
bEmendation yields “Who is a staff in the hand of my fury.”In whose hand, as a staff, is My fury!-b
text.9_Chapter, 5_Verse:
I send him against an ungodly nation,
I charge him against a people that provokes Me,
To take its spoil and to seize its booty
And to make it a thing trampled
Like the mire of the streets.
text.9_Chapter, 6_Verse:
But he has evil plans,
His mind harbors evil designs;
For he means to destroy,
To wipe out nations, not a few.
text.9_Chapter, 7_Verse:
For he thinks,
“After all, cEmendation yields “all the kingdoms fared alike!”I have kings as my captains!-c
text.9_Chapter, 8_Verse:
Was Calno any different from Carchemish?
Or Hamath from Arpad?
Or Samaria from Damascus?
text.9_Chapter, 9_Verse:
dEmendation yields “Since I was able to seize / those kingdoms and their images, / Why is Jerusalem better than Samaria?”Since I was able to seize
The insignificant kingdoms,
Whose images exceeded
Jerusalem’s and Samaria’s,-d
text.9_Chapter, 10_Verse:
Shall I not do to Jerusalem and her images
What I did to Samaria and her idols?”
text.9_Chapter, 11_Verse: But when my Lord has carried out all his purpose on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, HeeHeb. “I.” will punish the majestic pride and overbearing arrogance of the king of Assyria.
text.9_Chapter, 12_Verse:
For he thought,
“By the might of my hand have I wrought it,
By my skill, for I am clever:
I have erased the borders of peoples;
I have plundered their treasures,
And exiled their vast populations.fAccording to vv. 6–7, Assyria was to plunder, but not to exile.
text.9_Chapter, 13_Verse:
I was able to seize, like a nest,
The wealth of peoples;
As one gathers abandoned eggs,
So I gathered all the earth:
Nothing so much as flapped a wing
Or opened a mouth to peep.”
text.9_Chapter, 14_Verse:
Does an ax boast over him who hews with it,
Or a saw magnify itself above him who wields it?
As though the rod raised him who lifts it,
As though the staff lifted the man!gLit. “not-wood.”
text.9_Chapter, 15_Verse:
Assuredly,
The Sovereign LORD of Hosts will send
A wasting away in itshPresumably Israel’s. These verses would read well after 9.16. fatness;
And under its bodyiCf. note at v. 3. shall burn
A burning like that of fire,
jBrought up from v. 18 for clarity.Destroying frame and flesh.
It shall be like a sick man who pines away.-j
text.9_Chapter, 16_Verse:
The Light of Israel will be fire
And its Holy One flame.
It will burn and consume its thorns
And its thistles in a single day,
text.9_Chapter, 17_Verse: And the mass of its scrub and its farm land.
text.9_Chapter, 18_Verse:
What trees remain of its scrub
Shall be so few that a boy may record them.
text.9_Chapter, 19_Verse:
And in that day,
The remnant of Israel
And the escaped of the House of Jacob
Shall lean no more upon him that beats it,kI.e., upon Assyria (see v. 24). Ahaz’s reliance on Assyria was interpreted by Isaiah as lack of faith in the Lord; see 7.13 with note.
But shall lean sincerely
On the LORD, the Holy One of Israel.
text.9_Chapter, 20_Verse:
Only a remnant shall return,
Only a remnant of Jacob,
To Mighty God.
text.9_Chapter, 21_Verse:
Even if your people, O Israel,
Should be as the sands of the sea,
Only a remnant of it shall return.
Destruction is decreed;
Retribution comes like a flood!
text.9_Chapter, 22_Verse:
For my Lord GOD of Hosts is carrying out
A decree of destruction upon all the land.
text.9_Chapter, 23_Verse: Assuredly, thus said my Lord G<small>OD</small> of Hosts: “O My people that dwells in Zion, have no fear of Assyria, who beats you with a rod and wields his staff over you as did the Egyptians.
text.9_Chapter, 24_Verse: For very soon My wrath will have spent itself, and lPresumably Assyria; meaning of Heb. uncertain. Emendation yields “My anger against the world shall cease.”My anger that was bent on wasting them.”-l
text.9_Chapter, 25_Verse: The LORD of Hosts will brandish a scourge over him as when He beat Midian at the Rock of Oreb,mSee Judg. 7.25. and will wield His staff as He did over the Egyptians by the sea.
text.9_Chapter, 26_Verse:
And in that day,
His burden shall drop from your back,
nEmendation yields “And his yoke shall leave your neck. / He came up from Jeshimon / 28By the ascent of Aiath, / He proceeded to Migron; / At Michmas he commanded his forces: / 29‘Make the crossing; / Geba is to be our night quarters!’” Jeshimon is the southeast corner of the Jordan Valley, Num. 21.20; 23.28; Aiath is elsewhere called Ai.And his yoke from your neck;
The yoke shall be destroyed because of fatness.
text.9_Chapter, 27_Verse:
He advanced upon Aiath,
He proceeded to Migron,
At Michmas he deposited his baggage.
text.9_Chapter, 28_Verse:
They made the crossing;
“Geba is to be our night quarters!”-n
Ramah was alarmed;
Gibeah of Saul took to flight.
text.9_Chapter, 29_Verse:
“Give a shrill cry, O Bath-gallim!
Hearken, Laishah!
Take up the cry, Anathoth!”
text.9_Chapter, 30_Verse:
Madmenah ran away;
The dwellers of Gebim sought refuge.
text.9_Chapter, 31_Verse:
This same day at Nob
He shall stand and wave his hand.oI.e., the Assyrian king, arriving at Nob (close to Jerusalem), shall beckon his army onward; cf. 13.2.

O mount of Fair Zion!
O hill of Jerusalem!
text.9_Chapter, 32_Verse:
Lo! The Sovereign LORD of Hosts
Will hew off the tree-crowns with an ax:
The tall ones shall be felled,
The lofty ones cut down:
text.9_Chapter, 33_Verse:
The thickets of the forest shall be hacked away with iron,
And the Lebanon trees shall fall pOr “by the bronze,” connecting Heb. ’addir with Akkadian urudu, “bronze.”in their majesty.-p
text.10_Chapter, 0_Verse:
But a shoot shall grow out of the stump of Jesse,
A twig shall sprout from his stock.
text.10_Chapter, 1_Verse:
The spirit of the LORD shall alight upon him:
A spirit of wisdom and insight,
A spirit of counsel and valor,
A spirit of devotion and reverence for the LORD.
text.10_Chapter, 2_Verse:
aLit. “His sensing [shall be]”; meaning of Heb. uncertain.He shall sense the truth-a by his reverence for the LORD:
He shall not judge by what his eyes behold,
Nor decide by what his ears perceive.
text.10_Chapter, 3_Verse:
Thus he shall judge the poor with equity
And decide with justice for the lowly of the land.
He shall strike down a landbEmendation yields “the ruthless.” with the rod of his mouth
And slay the wicked with the breath of his lips.
text.10_Chapter, 4_Verse:
Justice shall be the girdle of his loins,
And faithfulness the girdle of his waist.
text.10_Chapter, 5_Verse:
The wolf shall dwell with the lamb,
The leopard lie down with the kid;
c1QIsa reads: “The calf and the beast of prey shall feed”; so too the Septuagint.The calf, the beast of prey, and the fatling-c together,
With a little boy to herd them.
text.10_Chapter, 6_Verse:
The cow and the bear shall graze,
Their young shall lie down together;
And the lion, like the ox, shall eat straw.
text.10_Chapter, 7_Verse:
A babe shall play
Over a viper’s hole,
And an infant passdMeaning of Heb. uncertain. his hand
Over an adder’s den.
text.10_Chapter, 8_Verse:
In all of eI.e., the Holy Land; cf. Exod. 15.17; Ps. 78.54.My sacred mount-e
Nothing evil or vile shall be done;
For the land shall be filled with devotion to the LORD
As water covers the sea.
text.10_Chapter, 9_Verse:
In that day,
The stock of Jesse that has remained standing
Shall become a standard to peoples—
Nations shall seek his counsel
And his abode shall be honored.
text.10_Chapter, 10_Verse: In that day, my Lord will apply His hand again to redeeming the other partfI.e., the part outside the Holy Land; lit. “the rest that will remain.” of His people from Assyria—as also from Egypt, Pathros, Nubia, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and the coastlands.
text.10_Chapter, 11_Verse:
He will hold up a signal to the nations
And assemble the banished of Israel,
And gather the dispersed of Judah
From the four corners of the earth.
text.10_Chapter, 12_Verse:
Then Ephraim’s envy shall cease
And Judah’s harassment shall end;
Ephraim shall not envy Judah,
And Judah shall not harass Ephraim.
text.10_Chapter, 13_Verse:
They shall pounce on the back of Philistia to the west,
And together plunder the peoples of the east;
Edom and Moab shall be subject to them
And the children of Ammon shall obey them.
text.10_Chapter, 14_Verse: The LORD will dry up the tongue of the Egyptian sea.—He will raise His hand over the Euphrates with the mightdMeaning of Heb. uncertain. of His wind and break it into seven wadis, so that it can be trodden dry-shod.
text.10_Chapter, 15_Verse: Thus there shall be a highway for the other partfI.e., the part outside the Holy Land; lit. “the rest that will remain.” of His people out of Assyria, such as there was for Israel when it left the land of Egypt.
text.11_Chapter, 0_Verse:
In that day, you shall say:
“I give thanks to You, O LORD!
Although You were wroth with me,
Your wrath has turned back and You comfort me,
text.11_Chapter, 1_Verse:
Behold the God who gives me triumph!
I am confident, unafraid;
For Yah the LORD is my strength and might,aOthers “song.”
And He has been my deliverance.”
text.11_Chapter, 2_Verse:
Joyfully shall you draw water
From the fountains of triumph,
text.11_Chapter, 3_Verse:
And you shall say on that day:
“Praise the LORD, proclaim His name.
Make His deeds known among the peoples;
Declare that His name is exalted.
text.11_Chapter, 4_Verse:
Hymn the LORD,
For He has done gloriously;
Let this be made known
In all the world!
text.11_Chapter, 5_Verse:
Oh, shout for joy,
You who dwell in Zion!
For great in your midst
Is the Holy One of Israel.”
text.12_Chapter, 0_Verse: The “Babylon” Pronouncement, a prophecy of Isaiah son of Amoz.
text.12_Chapter, 1_Verse:
“Raise a standard upon a bare hill,
Cry aloud to them;
Wave a hand, and let them enter
The gates of the nobles!
text.12_Chapter, 2_Verse:
I have summoned My purified guests
To execute My wrath;
Behold, I have called My stalwarts,
My proudly exultant ones.”aThe impending slaughter is spoken of as a sacrificial meal, for which the guests were notified to purify themselves ritually; cf. Zeph. 1.7.
text.12_Chapter, 3_Verse:
Hark! a tumult on the mountains—
As ofbMeaning of Heb. uncertain. a mighty force;
Hark! an uproar of kingdoms,
Nations assembling!
The LORD of Hosts is mustering
A host for war.
text.12_Chapter, 4_Verse:
They come from a distant land,
From the end of the sky—
The LORD with the weapons of His wrath—
To ravage all the earth!
text.12_Chapter, 5_Verse:
Howl!
For the day of the LORD is near;
It shall come like havoc from Shaddai.cTraditionally rendered “the Almighty.”
text.12_Chapter, 6_Verse:
Therefore all hands shall grow limp,
And all men’s hearts shall sink;
text.12_Chapter, 7_Verse:
And, overcome by terror,
They shall be seized by pangs and throes,
Writhe like a woman in travail.
They shall gaze at each other in horror,

text.12_Chapter, 8_Verse:

text.23_Chapter, 0_Verse:

And lay it waste,
And twist its surface,
And scatter its inhabitants.

Slave and master,
Handmaid and mistress,
Buyer and seller,
Lender and borrower,
Creditor and debtor.

It shall be plundered, plundered;
For it is the LORD who spoke this word.

And the stench of their corpses shall mount;

text.33_Chapter, 3_Verse:
a1QIsa reads “And the valleys shall be cleft, / And all the host of heaven shall wither.”All the host of heaven shall molder.-a
The heavens shall be rolled up like a scroll,
And all their host shall wither
Like a leaf withering on the vine,
Or shriveled fruit on a fig tree.
text.33_Chapter, 4_Verse:
For My sword shall b1QIsa reads “be seen”; cf. Targum.be drunk-b in the sky;
Lo, it shall come down upon Edom,
Upon the people I have doomed,
To wreak judgment.
text.33_Chapter, 5_Verse:
The LORD has a sword; it is sated with blood,
It is gorged with fat—
The blood of lambs and he-goats,
The kidney fat of rams.
For the LORD holds a sacrifice in Bozrah,
A great slaughter in the land of Edom.
text.33_Chapter, 6_Verse:
Wild oxen shall fall cEmendation yields “with fatted calves.”with them,-c
Young bulls with mighty steers;
And their land shall be drunk with blood,
Their soil shall be saturated with fat.
text.33_Chapter, 7_Verse:
For it is the LORD’s day of retribution,
The year of vindication for Zion’s cause.
text.33_Chapter, 8_Verse:
ItsdI.e., Edom’s. streams shall be turned to pitch
And its soil to sulfur.
Its land shall become burning pitch,
text.33_Chapter, 9_Verse:
Night and day it shall never go out;
Its smoke shall rise for all time.
Through the ages it shall lie in ruins;
Through the aeons none shall traverse it.
text.33_Chapter, 10_Verse:
eMeaning of Heb. uncertain.Jackdaws and owls-e shall possess it;
Great owls and ravens shall dwell there.
He shall measure it with a line of chaos
And with weights of emptiness.fI.e., He shall plan chaos and emptiness for it; cf. 28.17; Lam. 2.8.
text.33_Chapter, 11_Verse:
eMeaning of Heb. uncertain.It shall be called, “No kingdom is there,”-e
Its nobles and all its lords shall be nothing.
text.33_Chapter, 12_Verse:
Thorns shall grow up in its palaces,
Nettles and briers in its strongholds.
It shall be a home of jackals,
An abode of ostriches.
text.33_Chapter, 13_Verse:
gMost of the creatures in vv. 14–15 cannot be identified with certainty.Wildcats shall meet hyenas,
Goat-demons shall greet each other;
There too the lilithhA kind of demon. shall repose
And find herself a resting place.
text.33_Chapter, 14_Verse:
There the arrow-snake shall nest and lay eggs,
And shall brood and hatch in its shade.
There too the buzzards shall gather
With one another.
text.33_Chapter, 15_Verse:
Search and read it in the scroll of the LORD:
Not one of these shall be absent,
Not one shall miss its fellow.
For HisiHeb. “My.” mouth has spoken,
It is His spirit that has assembled them,
text.33_Chapter, 16_Verse:
And it is He who apportioned it to them by lot,
Whose hand divided it for them with the line.
They shall possess it for all time,
They shall dwell there through the ages.
text.34_Chapter, 0_Verse:
The arid desert shall be glad,
The wilderness shall rejoice
And shall blossom like a rose.aLit. “crocus.”
text.34_Chapter, 1_Verse:
It shall blossom abundantly,
It shall also exult and shout.
It shall receive the glory of Lebanon,
The splendor of Carmel and Sharon.
They shall behold the glory of the LORD,
The splendor of our God.
text.34_Chapter, 2_Verse:
Strengthen the hands that are slack;
Make firm the tottering knees!
text.34_Chapter, 3_Verse:
Say to the anxious of heart,
“Be strong, fear not;
Behold your God!
Requital is coming,
The recompense of God—
He Himself is coming to give you triumph.”
text.34_Chapter, 4_Verse:
Then the eyes of the blind shall be opened,
And the ears of the deaf shall be unstopped.
text.34_Chapter, 5_Verse:
Then the lame shall leap like a deer,
And the tongue of the dumb shall shout aloud;
For waters shall burst forth in the desert,
Streams in the wilderness.
text.34_Chapter, 6_Verse:
Torrid earth shall become a pool;
Parched land, fountains of water;
The home of jackals, a pasture;bMeaning of Heb. uncertain; emendation yields “a marsh.”
The abode [of ostriches],cCf. 34.13. reeds and rushes.
text.34_Chapter, 7_Verse:
And a highway shall appear there,
Which shall be called the Sacred Way.
No one unclean shall pass along it,
But it shall be for them.dEmendation yields “for His people.”
eMeaning of Heb. uncertain.No traveler, not even fools, shall go astray.-e
text.34_Chapter, 8_Verse:
No lion shall be there,
No ferocious beast shall set foot on it—
These shall not be found there.
But the redeemed shall walk it;
text.34_Chapter, 9_Verse:
And the ransomed of the LORD shall return,
And come with shouting to Zion,
Crowned with joy everlasting.
They shall attain joy and gladness,
While sorrow and sighing flee.
text.35_Chapter, 0_Verse: aChaps. 36–39 occur also as 2 Kings 18.13–20.19, with a number of variants, some of which will be cited here in the footnotes.In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, King Sennacherib of Assyria marched against all the fortified towns of Judah and seized them.
text.35_Chapter, 1_Verse: From Lachish, the king of Assyria sent the Rabshakeh,bAn Assyrian title; cf. “Tartan,” 20.1. with a large force, to King Hezekiah in Jerusalem. [The Rabshakeh] took up a position near the conduit of the Upper Pool, by the road of the Fuller’s Field;
text.35_Chapter, 2_Verse: and Eliakim son of Hilkiah who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the scribe, and Joah son of Asaph the recorder went out to him.
text.35_Chapter, 3_Verse: The Rabshakeh said to them, “You tell Hezekiah: Thus said the Great King, the king of Assyria: What makes you so confident?
text.35_Chapter, 4_Verse: I supposec2 Kings 18.20 “You must think.” mere talk makes counsel and valor for war! Look, on whom are you relying, that you have rebelled against me?
text.35_Chapter, 5_Verse: You are relying on Egypt, that splintered reed of a staff, which enters and punctures the palm of anyone who leans on it. That’s what Pharaoh king of Egypt is like to all who rely on him.
text.35_Chapter, 6_Verse: And if you tell me that you are relying on the L<small>ORD</small> your God, He is the very one whose shrines and altars Hezekiah did away with, telling Judah and Jerusalem, ‘You must worship only at this altar!’
text.35_Chapter, 7_Verse: Come now, make this wager with my master, the king of Assyria: I’ll give you two thousand horses, if you can produce riders to mount them.
text.35_Chapter, 8_Verse: So how could you refuse anything, even to the deputy of one of my master’s lesser servants, relying on Egypt for chariots and horsemen?
text.35_Chapter, 9_Verse: And do you think I have marched against this land to destroy it without the L<small>ORD</small>? The L<small>ORD</small> Himself told me: Go up against that land and destroy it.”
text.35_Chapter, 10_Verse: Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah replied to the Rabshakeh, “Please, speak to your servants in Aramaic, since we understand it; do not speak to us in Judean in the hearing of the people on the wall.”
text.35_Chapter, 11_Verse: But the Rabshakeh replied, “Was it to your master and to you that my master sent me to speak those words? It was precisely to the men who are sitting on the wall—who will have to eat their dung and drink their urine with you.”
text.35_Chapter, 12_Verse: And the Rabshakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in Judean:
text.35_Chapter, 13_Verse: “Hear the words of the Great King, the king of Assyria! Thus said the king: Don’t let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will not be able to save you.
text.35_Chapter, 14_Verse: Don’t let Hezekiah make you rely on the L<small>ORD</small>, saying, ‘The L<small>ORD</small> will surely save us; this city will not fall into the hands of Assyria!’
text.35_Chapter, 15_Verse: Don’t listen to Hezekiah. For thus said the king of Assyria: Make your peace with me and come out to me,dI.e., to my representative the Rabshakeh. so that you may all eat from your vines and your fig trees and drink water from your cisterns,
text.35_Chapter, 16_Verse: until I come and take you away to a land like your own, a land of bread and wine, of grain [fields] and vineyards.
text.35_Chapter, 17_Verse: Beware of letting Hezekiah mislead you by saying, ‘The L<small>ORD</small> will save us.’ Did any of the gods of the other nations save his land from the king of Assyria?
text.35_Chapter, 18_Verse: Where were the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where were the gods of Sepharvaim? And did theyeI.e., the gods of Samaria. save Samaria from me?
text.35_Chapter, 19_Verse: Which among all the gods of those countries saved their countries from me, that the L<small>ORD</small> should save Jerusalem from me?”
text.35_Chapter, 20_Verse: But they were silent and did not answer him with a single word; for the king’s order was: “Do not answer him.”
text.35_Chapter, 21_Verse: And so Eliakim son of Hilkiah who was in charge of the palace, Shebna the scribe, and Joah son of Asaph the recorder came to Hezekiah with their clothes rent, and they reported to him what the Rabshakeh had said.
text.36_Chapter, 0_Verse: When King Hezekiah heard this, he rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth and went into the House of the L<small>ORD</small>.
text.36_Chapter, 1_Verse: He also sent Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace, Shebna, the scribe, and the senior priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.
text.36_Chapter, 2_Verse: They said to him, “Thus said Hezekiah: This day is a day of distress, of chastisement, and of disgrace. aI.e., the situation is desperate, and we are at a loss.The babes have reached the birthstool, but the strength to give birth is lacking.-a
text.36_Chapter, 3_Verse: Perhaps the L<small>ORD</small> your God will take note of the words of the Rabshakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to blaspheme the living God, and will mete out judgment for the words that the L<small>ORD</small> your God has heard—if you will offer up prayer for the surviving remnant.”
text.36_Chapter, 4_Verse: When King Hezekiah’s ministers came to Isaiah,
text.36_Chapter, 5_Verse: Isaiah said to them, “Tell your master as follows: Thus said the L<small>ORD</small>: Do not be frightened by the words of blasphemy against Me that you have heard from the minions of the king of Assyria.
text.36_Chapter, 6_Verse: I will deludebLit. “put a spirit in.” him: He will hear a rumor and return to his land, and I will make him fall by the sword in his land.”
text.36_Chapter, 7_Verse: The Rabshakeh, meanwhile, heard that [the King] had left Lachish; he turned back and found the king of Assyria attacking Libnah.
text.36_Chapter, 8_Verse: But [the king of Assyria] learned that King Tirhakah of Nubia had come out to fight him; and when he heard it, he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,
text.36_Chapter, 9_Verse: “Tell this to King Hezekiah of Judah: Do not let your God, on whom you are relying, mislead you into thinking that Jerusalem will not be delivered into the hands of the king of Assyria.
text.36_Chapter, 10_Verse: You yourself have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the lands, how they have annihilated them; and can you escape?
text.36_Chapter, 11_Verse: Were the nations that my predecessorscLit. “fathers.” destroyed—Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the Bethedenites in Telassar—saved by their gods?
text.36_Chapter, 12_Verse: Where is the king of Hamath? and the king of Arpad? and the kings of Lair, Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah?”
text.36_Chapter, 13_Verse: Hezekiah received the letter from the messengers and read it. Hezekiah then went up to the House of the L<small>ORD</small> and spread it out before the L<small>ORD</small>.
text.36_Chapter, 14_Verse: And Hezekiah prayed to the L<small>ORD</small>:
text.36_Chapter, 15_Verse: “O L<small>ORD</small> of Hosts, enthroned on the Cherubim! You alone are God of all the kingdoms of the earth. You made the heavens and the earth.
text.36_Chapter, 16_Verse: O L<small>ORD</small>, incline Your ear and hear, open Your eye and see. Hear all the words that Sennacherib has sent to blaspheme the living God!
text.36_Chapter, 17_Verse: True, O LORD, the kings of Assyria have annihilated all the nationsdSo 2 Kings 19.17, and 13 mss. here; most mss. and editions read “lands.” and their lands
text.36_Chapter, 18_Verse: and have committed their gods to the flames and have destroyed them; for they are not gods, but man’s handwork of wood and stone.
text.36_Chapter, 19_Verse: But now, O LORD our God, deliver us from his hands, and let all the kingdoms of the earth know that You, O LORD, alone [are God].”eSupplied from 2 Kings 19.19.
text.36_Chapter, 20_Verse: Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent this message to Hezekiah: “Thus said the L<small>ORD</small>, the God of Israel, to whom you have prayed, concerning King Sennacherib of Assyria—
text.36_Chapter, 21_Verse:
this is the word that the LORD has spoken concerning him:

Fair Maiden Zion despises you,
She mocks at you;
Fair Jerusalem shakes
Her head at you.
text.36_Chapter, 22_Verse:
Whom have you blasphemed and reviled?
Against whom made loud your voice
And haughtily raised your eyes?
Against the Holy One of Israel!
text.36_Chapter, 23_Verse:
Through your servants you have blasphemed my Lord.
Because you thought,
‘Thanks to my vast chariotry,
It is I who have climbed the highest mountains,
To the remotest parts of the Lebanon,
And have cut down its loftiest cedars,
Its choicest cypresses,
And have reached its highest peak,
fLit. “Its farmland forest”; exact meaning of Heb. uncertain.Its densest forest.-f
text.36_Chapter, 24_Verse:
It is I who have drawngOr “dug”; meaning of Heb. uncertain.
And drunk water.
I have dried up with the soles of my feet
All the streams of Egypt.’
text.36_Chapter, 25_Verse:
Have you not heard? Of old
I planned that very thing,
I designed it long ago,
And now have fulfilled it.
And it has come to pass,
Laying fortified towns waste in desolate heaps.
text.36_Chapter, 26_Verse:
Their inhabitants are helpless,
Dismayed and shamed.
They were but grass of the field
And green herbage,
Grass of the roofs hSo ms. 1QIsa; cf. 2 Kings 19.26. The usual reading in our passage means, literally, “and a field [?] before standing grain.”that is blasted
Before the east wind.-h
text.36_Chapter, 27_Verse:
I know your stayings
And your goings and comings,
And how you have raged against Me,
text.36_Chapter, 28_Verse:
Because you have raged against Me,
And your tumult has reached My ears,
I will place My hook in your nose
And My bit between your jaws;
And I will make you go back by the road
By which you came.
text.36_Chapter, 29_Verse: “And this is the sign for you:iI.e., Hezekiah. This year you eat what grows of itself, and the next year what springs from that, and in the third year sow and reap and plant vineyards and eat their fruit.
text.36_Chapter, 30_Verse: And the survivors of the House of Judah that have escaped shall renew its trunk below and produce boughs above.
text.36_Chapter, 31_Verse:
For a remnant shall come forth from Jerusalem,
Survivors from Mount Zion.
The zeal of the LORD of Hosts
Shall bring this to pass.
text.36_Chapter, 32_Verse:
“Assuredly, thus said the LORD concerning the king of Assyria:

He shall not enter this city;
He shall not shoot an arrow at it,
Or advance upon it with a shield,
Or pile up a siegemound against it.
text.36_Chapter, 33_Verse:
He shall go back
By the way he came,
He shall not enter this city
—declares the LORD;
text.36_Chapter, 34_Verse:
I will protect and save this city for My sake
And for the sake of My servant David.”
text.36_Chapter, 35_Verse: [That night]jSupplied from 2 Kings 19.35. an angel of the LORD went out and struck down one hundred and eighty-five thousand in the Assyrian camp, and the following morning they were all dead corpses.
text.36_Chapter, 36_Verse: So King Sennacherib of Assyria broke camp and retreated, and stayed in Nineveh.
text.36_Chapter, 37_Verse: While he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, he was struck down with the sword by his sons Adrammelech and Sarezer. They fled to the land of Ararat, and his son Esarhaddon succeeded him as king.
text.37_Chapter, 0_Verse: In those days Hezekiah fell dangerously ill. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came and said to him, “Thus said the L<small>ORD</small>: Set your affairs in order, for you are going to die; you will not get well.”
text.37_Chapter, 1_Verse: Thereupon Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the L<small>ORD</small>.
text.37_Chapter, 2_Verse: “Please, O L<small>ORD</small>,” he said, “remember how I have walked before You sincerely and wholeheartedly, and have done what is pleasing to You.” And Hezekiah wept profusely.
text.37_Chapter, 3_Verse: Then the word of the L<small>ORD</small> came to Isaiah:
text.37_Chapter, 4_Verse: “Go and tell Hezekiah: Thus said the L<small>ORD</small>, the God of your father David: I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears. I hereby add fifteen years to your life.
text.37_Chapter, 5_Verse: I will also rescue you and this city from the hands of the king of Assyria. I will protect this city.
text.37_Chapter, 6_Verse: And this is the sign for you from the L<small>ORD</small> that the L<small>ORD</small> will do the thing that He has promised:
text.37_Chapter, 7_Verse: I am going to make the shadow on the steps, which has descended on the dialaHeb. “steps.” A model of a dial with steps has been discovered in Egypt. of Ahaz because of the sun, recede ten steps.” And the sun[’s shadow] receded ten steps, the same steps as it had descended.
text.37_Chapter, 8_Verse: A poem by King Hezekiah of Judah when he recovered from the illness he had suffered:
text.37_Chapter, 9_Verse:
bMeaning of verse uncertain. in part.I had thought:
I must depart in the middle of my days;
I have been consigned to the gates of Sheol
For the rest of my years.
text.37_Chapter, 10_Verse:
I thought, I shall never see Yah,cI.e., visit His Temple. For “Yah” see 12.2; 26.4.
Yah in the land of the living,
Or ever behold men again
Among those who inhabit the earth.
text.37_Chapter, 11_Verse:
My dwelling is pulled up and removed from me
Like a tent of shepherds;
My life is rolled up like a web
And cut from the thrum.

dMeaning of Heb. uncertain.Only from daybreak to nightfall
Was I kept whole,
text.37_Chapter, 12_Verse:
Then it was as though a lion
Were breaking all my bones;
I cried out until morning.
(Only from daybreak to nightfall
Was I kept whole.)-d
text.37_Chapter, 13_Verse:
I piped like a swift or a swallow,
I moaned like a dove,
As my eyes, all worn, looked to heaven:
“My Lord, I am in straits;
Be my surety!”
text.37_Chapter, 14_Verse:
What can I say? dMeaning of Heb. uncertain.He promised me,-d
And He it is who has wrought it.
-dAll my sleep had fled
Because of the bitterness of my soul.
text.37_Chapter, 15_Verse:
My Lord, for all that and despite it
My life-breath is revived;-d
You have restored me to health and revived me.
text.37_Chapter, 16_Verse:
Truly, it was for my own good
That I had such great bitterness:
You saved my life
From the pit of destruction,
For You have cast behind Your back
All my offenses.
text.37_Chapter, 17_Verse:
For it is not Sheol that praises You,
Not [the Land of] Death that extols You;
Nor do they who descend into the Pit
Hope for Your grace.
text.37_Chapter, 18_Verse:
The living, only the living
Can give thanks to You
As I do this day;
FatherseHeb. singular. relate to children
Your acts of grace:
text.37_Chapter, 19_Verse:
“[It has pleased] the LORD to deliver us,eHeb. singular.
That is why we offer up musicfNeginothai is a poetic form of neginoth.
All the days of our lives
At the House of the LORD.”
text.37_Chapter, 20_Verse: When Isaiah said, “Let them take a cake of figs and apply it to the rash, and he will recover,”
text.37_Chapter, 21_Verse: Hezekiah asked, “What will be the sign that I shall go up to the House of the L<small>ORD</small>?”
text.38_Chapter, 0_Verse: At that time, Merodach-baladan son of Baladan, the king of Babylon, sent [envoys with] a letter and a gift to Hezekiah, for he had heard about his illness and recovery.
text.38_Chapter, 1_Verse: Hezekiah was pleased by their coming, and he showed them his treasure house—the silver, the gold, the spices, and the fragrant oil—and all his armory, and everything that was to be found in his storehouses. There was nothing in his palace or in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.
text.38_Chapter, 2_Verse: Then the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah. “What,” he demanded of him, “did those men say to you? Where have they come to you from?” “They have come to me,” replied Hezekiah, “from a far country, from Babylon.”
text.38_Chapter, 3_Verse: Next he asked, “What have they seen in your palace?” And Hezekiah replied, “They have seen everything there is in my palace. There was nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them.”
text.38_Chapter, 4_Verse: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the L<small>ORD</small> of Hosts:
text.38_Chapter, 5_Verse: A time is coming when everything in your palace, which your ancestors have stored up to this day, will be carried off to Babylon; nothing will be left behind, said the L<small>ORD</small>.
text.38_Chapter, 6_Verse: And some of your sons, your own issue, whom you will have fathered, will be taken to serve as eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”
text.38_Chapter, 7_Verse: Hezekiah declared to Isaiah, “The word of the LORD that you have spoken is good.” For he thought, “It means that aLit. “there shall be safety and faithfulness in.”safety is assured for-a my time.”
text.39_Chapter, 0_Verse:
Comfort, oh comfort My people,
Says your God.
text.39_Chapter, 1_Verse:
Speak tenderly to Jerusalem,
And declare to her
That her term of service is over,
That her iniquity is expiated;
For she has received at the hand of the LORD
Double for all her sins.
text.39_Chapter, 2_Verse:
A voice rings out:
“Clear in the desert
A road for the LORD!
Level in the wilderness
A highway for our God!
text.39_Chapter, 3_Verse:
Let every valley be raised,
Every hill and mount made low.
Let the rugged ground become level
And the ridges become a plain.
text.39_Chapter, 4_Verse:
The Presence of the LORD shall appear,
And all flesh, as one, shall behold—
For the LORD Himself has spoken.”
text.39_Chapter, 5_Verse:
A voice rings out: “Proclaim!”
a1QIsa and Septuagint read “And I asked.”Another asks,-a “What shall I proclaim?”
“All flesh is grass,
All its goodness like flowers of the field:
text.39_Chapter, 6_Verse:
Grass withers, flowers fade
When the breath of the LORD blows on them.
Indeed, man is but grass:
text.39_Chapter, 7_Verse:
Grass withers, flowers fade—
But the word of our God is always fulfilled!”
text.39_Chapter, 8_Verse:
Ascend a lofty mountain,
O herald of joy to Zion;
Raise your voice with power,
O herald of joy to Jerusalem—
Raise it, have no fear;
Announce to the cities of Judah:
Behold your God!
text.39_Chapter, 9_Verse:
Behold, the Lord GOD comes in might,
And His arm wins triumph for Him;
See, His rewardbThe reward and recompense to the cities of Judah; cf. Jer. 31.14, 16. is with Him,
His recompense before Him.
text.39_Chapter, 10_Verse:
Like a shepherd He pastures His flock:
He gathers the lambs in His arms
And carries them in His bosom;
Gently He drives the mother sheep.
text.39_Chapter, 11_Verse:
Who measured the waters with the hollow of His hand,
And gauged the skies with a span,
And meted earth’s dust with a measure,cHeb. shalish “third,” probably a third of an ephah.
And weighed the mountains with a scale
And the hills with a balance?
text.39_Chapter, 12_Verse:
Who has plumbed the mind of the LORD,
What man could tell Him His plan?
text.39_Chapter, 13_Verse:
Whom did He consult, and who taught Him,
Guided Him in the way of right?
Who guided Him in knowledge
And showed Him the path of wisdom?
text.39_Chapter, 14_Verse:
The nations are but a drop in a bucket,
Reckoned as dust on a balance;
The very coastlands He lifts like motes.
text.39_Chapter, 15_Verse:
Lebanon is not fuel enough,
Nor its beasts enough for sacrifice.
text.39_Chapter, 16_Verse:
All nations are as naught in His sight;
He accounts them as less than nothing.
text.39_Chapter, 17_Verse:
To whom, then, can you liken God,
What form compare to Him?
text.39_Chapter, 18_Verse:
The idol? A woodworker shaped it,
And a smith overlaid it with gold,
dMeaning of Heb. uncertain.Forging links of silver.-d
text.39_Chapter, 19_Verse:
As a gift, he chooses the mulberryeHeb. mesukkan; according to a Jewish tradition, preserved by Jerome, a kind of wood; a similar word denotes a kind of wood in Akkadian.—
A wood that does not rot—
Then seeks a skillful woodworker
To make a firm idol,
That will not topple.
text.39_Chapter, 20_Verse:
Do you not know?
Have you not heard?
Have you not been told
From the very first?
Have you not discerned
dMeaning of Heb. uncertain.How the earth was founded?-d
text.39_Chapter, 21_Verse:
It is He who is enthroned above the vault of the earth,
So that its inhabitants seem as grasshoppers;
Who spread out the skies like gauze,
Stretched them out like a tent to dwell in.
text.39_Chapter, 22_Verse:
He brings potentates to naught,
Makes rulers of the earth as nothing.
text.39_Chapter, 23_Verse:
Hardly are they planted,
Hardly are they sown,
Hardly has their stem
Taken root in earth,
When He blows upon them and they dry up,
And the storm bears them off like straw.
text.39_Chapter, 24_Verse:
To whom, then, can you liken Me,
To whom can I be compared?
—says the Holy One.
text.39_Chapter, 25_Verse:
Lift high your eyes and see:
Who created these?
He who sends out their host by count,
Who calls them each by name:
Because of His great might and vast power,
Not one fails to appear.
text.39_Chapter, 26_Verse:
Why do you say, O Jacob,
Why declare, O Israel,
“My way is hid from the LORD,
My cause is ignored by my God”?
text.39_Chapter, 27_Verse:
Do you not know?
Have you not heard?
The LORD is God from of old,
Creator of the earth from end to end,
He never grows faint or weary,
His wisdom cannot be fathomed.
text.39_Chapter, 28_Verse:
He gives strength to the weary,
Fresh vigor to the spent.
text.39_Chapter, 29_Verse:
Youths may grow faint and weary,
And young men stumble and fall;
text.39_Chapter, 30_Verse:
But they who trust in the LORD shall renew their strength
As eagles grow new plumes:fAlluding to a popular belief that eagles regain their youth when they molt; cf. Ps. 103.5.
They shall run and not grow weary,
They shall march and not grow faint.
text.40_Chapter, 0_Verse:
Stand silent before Me, coastlands,
And let nations aConnection of Heb. uncertain.renew their strength.-a
Let them approach to state their case;
Let us come forward together for argument.
text.40_Chapter, 1_Verse:
Who has roused a victorbLit. “victory.” from the East,
Summoned him to His service?
Has delivered up nations to him,
And trodden sovereigns down?
Has rendered theircHeb. “his.” swords like dust,
TheircHeb. “his.” bows like wind-blown straw?
text.40_Chapter, 2_Verse:
He pursues them, he goes on unscathed;
No shackled’rḥ has this meaning in Old Aramaic. is placed on his feet.
text.40_Chapter, 3_Verse:
Who has wrought and achieved this?
He who announced the generations from the start—
I, the LORD, who was first
And will be with the last as well.
text.40_Chapter, 4_Verse:
The coastlands look on in fear,
The ends of earth tremble.

They draw near and come;
text.40_Chapter, 5_Verse:
Each one helps the other,
Saying to his fellow, “Take courage!”
text.40_Chapter, 6_Verse:
The woodworker encourages the smith;
He who flattens with the hammer
[Encourages] him who pounds the anvil.
He says of the riveting, “It is good!”
And he fixes it with nails,
That it may not topple.
text.40_Chapter, 7_Verse:
But you, Israel, My servant,
Jacob, whom I have chosen,
Seed of Abraham My friend—
text.40_Chapter, 8_Verse:
You whom I drew from the ends of the earth
And called from its far corners,
To whom I said: You are My servant;
I chose you, I have not rejected you—
text.40_Chapter, 9_Verse:
Fear not, for I am with you,
Be not frightened, for I am your God;
I strengthen you and I help you,
I uphold you with My victorious right hand.
text.40_Chapter, 10_Verse:
Shamed and chagrined shall be
All who contend with you;
They who strive with you
Shall become as naught and shall perish.
text.40_Chapter, 11_Verse:
You may seek, but shall not find
Those who struggle with you;
Less than nothing shall be
The men who battle against you.
text.40_Chapter, 12_Verse:
For I the LORD am your God,
Who grasped your right hand,
Who say to you: Have no fear;
I will be your help.
text.40_Chapter, 13_Verse:
Fear not, O worm Jacob,
O eEmendation yields “maggot.”men of-e Israel:
I will help you
—declares the LORD—
I your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel.
text.40_Chapter, 14_Verse:
I will make of you a threshing board,
A new thresher, with many spikes;
You shall thresh mountains to dust,
And make hills like chaff.
text.40_Chapter, 15_Verse:
You shall winnow them
And the wind shall carry them off;
The whirlwind shall scatter them.
But you shall rejoice in the LORD,
And glory in the Holy One of Israel.
text.40_Chapter, 16_Verse:
The poor and the needy
Seek water,fI.e., on the homeward march through the desert. and there is none;
Their tongue is parched with thirst.
I the LORD will respond to them.
I, the God of Israel, will not forsake them.
text.40_Chapter, 17_Verse:
I will open up streams on the bare hills
And fountains amid the valleys;
I will turn the desert into ponds,
The arid land into springs of water.
text.40_Chapter, 18_Verse:
I will plant cedars in the wilderness,
Acacias and myrtles and oleasters;
I will set cypresses in the desert,
Box trees and elms as well—
text.40_Chapter, 19_Verse:
That men may see and know,
Consider and comprehend
That the LORD’s hand has done this,
That the Holy One of Israel has wrought it.
text.40_Chapter, 20_Verse:
Submit your case, says the LORD;
Offer your pleas, says the King of Jacob.
text.40_Chapter, 21_Verse:
Let them approachgTaking yaggishu intransitively; cf. hiqriv. Exod. 14.10. and tell us what will happen.
Tell us what has occurred,hI.e., former prophecies by your gods which have been fulfilled.
And we will take note of it;
Or announce to us what will occur,
That we may know the outcome.
text.40_Chapter, 22_Verse:
Foretell what is yet to happen,
That we may know that you are gods!
Do anything, good or bad,
That we may be awed and see.iChange of vocalization yields “fear”; cf. v. 10.
text.40_Chapter, 23_Verse:
Why, you are less than nothing,
Your effect is less than nullity;
One who chooses you is an abomination.
text.40_Chapter, 24_Verse:
I have roused him from the north, and he has come,
From the sunrise, one who invokes My name;
And he has trampled rulers like mud,
Like a potter treading clay.
text.40_Chapter, 25_Verse:
Who foretold this from the start, that we may note it;
From aforetime, that we might say, “He is right”?
Not one foretold, not one announced;
No one has heard your utterance!
text.40_Chapter, 26_Verse:
jMeaning of Heb. uncertain.The things once predicted to Zion—
Behold, here they are!-j
And again I send a herald to Jerusalem.
text.40_Chapter, 27_Verse:
But I look and there is not a man;
Not one of them can predict
Or can respond when I question him.
text.40_Chapter, 28_Verse:
See, they are all nothingness,
Their works are nullity,
Their statues are naught and nil.
text.41_Chapter, 0_Verse:
This is My servant, whom I uphold,
My chosen one, in whom I delight.
I have put My spirit upon him,
He shall teach the true way to the nations.
text.41_Chapter, 1_Verse:
